author: John Dagge and John Beveridge
title: Earnings hit ahead if commodities fail to recover
text:
THE widespread rout in ­commodity prices threatens to slash BHP Billiton’s earnings if there is no rebound, according to new research.
Investment bank UBS says earnings this year at the ­nation’s biggest company will come in 30 per cent below the bank’s original forecast if commodity prices stay at current levels.
Iron ore suffered its biggest one-day price fall on record overnight Wednesday, plunging a head-spinning 10.1 per cent to $US44.59 a tonne.
The key steelmaking ingredient — Australia’s biggest export earner — is at its lowest price since the daily spot price began being tracked in mid-2009.
It has lost ground for 10 consecutive trading sessions, shedding almost 30 per cent.
Yet it is not iron ore hurting the world’s biggest miner — with UBS having forecast the current dive — but weaker than expected prices across a range of other resources. These include BHP’s other big earners, petroleum and copper.
Commodity prices have been battered by ructions in China’s stockmarket that have sparked renewed concern about the health of the world’s second biggest economy.
Nickel has slumped 18.5 per cent, Brent crude oil 10 per cent, copper and zinc 7 per cent, silver 5 per cent and aluminium 4.5 per cent over the past month.
Even gold, usually a safe haven, is down 1.5 per cent over the month.
Dollars and Sense. Picture: Roy
The slide in nickel, zinc and silver means BHP spin-off South32’s earnings for the year to next June will be 56 per cent lower than UBS had previously forecast. South32 has made an underwhelming start to life on the market, with its shares closing at $1.755 on Thursday — about 18 per cent below its May listing price.
The UBS report was issued on Wednesday, before the latest iron ore plunge. UBS had pencilled in iron ore to average $US45 a tonne for the rest of the year before rising slightly to $US48 a tonne in 2016.
Using Wednesday’s spot price of $US47.08, Rio Tinto would take a 7 per cent hit to earnings while Fortescue’s would rise by 33 per cent.
The iron ore crash comes as struggling junior miner Atlas Iron taps investors for $180 million to shore up its balance sheet.
Managing director David Flanagan on Thursday told BusinessDaily the business was viable as it had locked in forward sales at prices ranging from $US53 to $US59 a tonne. He also revealed he was personally investing $200,000 and that he owned three million shares bought at $1.40 each.
